did.abstract: Serge Prokofiev (1891–1953) was a Russian and Soviet composer, pianist and conductor, and seminal figure in the history of twentieth-century music. The Serge Prokofiev Archive (SPA) contains 58 original music manuscripts and over 10,000 letters and documents primarily from 1918-1936, the years Prokofiev spent in the West. The SPA also includes an expansive collection of music manuscript copies, published scores, concert programs, scholarly books and articles, photographs, and audio and video material, making it the premier research collection for studying Prokofiev's life, work and legacy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Serge Prokofiev (1891–1953) was a Russian and Soviet composer, pianist and conductor, and seminal figure in the history of twentieth-century music. The Serge Prokofiev Archive (SPA) contains 58 original music manuscripts and over 10,000 letters and documents primarily from 1918-1936, the years Prokofiev spent in the West. The SPA also includes an expansive collection of music manuscript copies, published scores, concert programs, scholarly books and articles, photographs, and audio and video material, making it the premier research collection for studying Prokofiev's life, work and legacy

Constituted in successive stages, this impressive collection was gathered by Prokofiev himself, members of his family, and individuals dedicated to the composer's oeuvre. The core consists of Prokofiev's compositions, writings and records from his prolonged stay in the West - mainly the United States, France, and Germany - from 1918 to 1936. It includes 58 manuscript scores, drafts, sketches and notes for works such as Symphony Nos. 3 and 4, his operas The Gambler and The Fiery Angel, the Concerto for Piano Nos. 4 and 5, the ballets Sur le Borysthène and Le Pas d'Acier, the Sonata for Two Violins and String Quartet No. 1. Prokofiev's personal and professional letters and documents from this period, totalling over 10,000 items, inlcude correspondence with conductors Albert Coates, Sir Henry Wood, Sergei Koussevitzky,Hermann Scherchen, and Ernest Ansermet; soloists Joseph Szigeti, Pablo Casals, Robert Soetens, and Fedor Chaliapin; composers Igor Stravinsky and Nikolai Miaskovsky; directors Vsevolod Meyerhold and Alexander Tairov; Ballets Russes impresario Serge Diaghilev; and chess grandmaster Jose Capablanca. Prokofiev meticulously saved bills, accounts and legal papers concerning concerts in the United States, France, Italy, Spain, England, the Soviet Union, and Germany, as well as materials relating to the publication and copyright of his work.

When Prokofiev returned to Moscow in 1936, he took only those papers and manuscripts he judged necessary for his life in the Soviet Union. Everything else was left in the care of close Parisian friends and his publisher, Édition Russe de Musique. Most of this material was eventually deposited at the Bibliothèque nationale de France (BnF) in Paris, where it remained until 2013.

In the 1970s, Lina Prokofiev, the composer's first wife, left the Soviet Union and settled in the West. In the years that followed she devoted considerable energy to tracking down the composer's personal effects and papers and to promoting his legacy. She was able to access, and make photo and microfilm copies of, the Prokofiev material at the BnF. In 1983, she created The Serge Prokofiev Foundation. After Mme. Prokofiev's death in 1989, the musicologist Noëlle Mann continued this work, and in 1994 established the Serge Prokofiev Archive (SPA) at Goldsmiths College, University of London.

For nearly two decades, the SPA at Goldsmiths served as the authoritative research collection on Prokofiev in the West. It contained the copies of the Prokofiev materials at the BnF, as well as copies of other Prokofiev manuscripts, letters, photographs, and documents held in other repositories. The SPA gathered a vast collection of published material on Prokofiev, including some 500 scores (including many rare and first editions), nearly 500 concert programs, and over 400 books (mainly in English and Russian, but also in French and German), periodicals and articles on Prokofiev. The audiovisual collection contains almost 800 audio recordings on CD, LP and cassette, and 65 video/DVD recordings.

The Goldsmiths SPA also acquired archival material from the composer's family and devoted supporters. Lina Prokofiev donated her own personal archive, which includes materials gathered for a planned biography of her husband. Oleg Prokofiev, their younger son, donated material relating to his own work and to his father's music. Smaller archival collections added to the SPA archive include: the Georgii Gorchakov Collection, the Christopher Palmer Collection, the Lázár Collection, the Sir Edward Downes Collection, the Noëlle Mann Collection, and the Reberg Collection.

In 2013, the original Prokofiev material from the BnF and the Goldsmiths SPA were brought together to form one coherent collection, currently on deposit at the Rare Books and Manuscript Library at Columbia University.

The website of the Serge Prokofiev Foundation, www.sprkfv.net, contains further information about the life and works of the composer and the Archive. There is also information about the journal of the Prokofiev Foundation, Three Oranges, including some sample full-text articles, and information regarding subscriptions.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Material is arranged in ten series with several sub-series.
Series I: Music Manuscripts
Subseries I.1: Original manuscripts
Subseries I.2: Photocopies
Subseries I.3: Microfilm copies
Subseries I.4: Digital copies
Series II: Personal Papers
Subseries II.1: Personal and Business Correspondence
Subseries II.2: Financial material
Subseries II.3: Miscellaneous
Series III: Published Scores
Subseries III.1: Prokofiev Collected Works, Belwin Mills
Subseries III.2: Prokofiev Collected Works, Soviet State Music Publishing House (Gosudarstvennoe Muzykal'noe Izdatel'stvo)
Subseries III.3: Prokofiev works, Various publishers, Arranged by genre
Subseries III.4: Prokofiev works, Arrangements
Subseries III.5: Works by other composers
Subseries III.6: Oversize items
Subseries III.7: Duplicate items
Series IV: Concert Programs
Series V: Research Collection
Subseries V.1: Books
Subseries V.2: Periodicals
Series VI: Audio and Visual Material
Series VII: Photographs
Series VIII: Newspaper Clippings
Series IX: Family Papers
Subseries IX.1: Lina Prokofiev Papers
Subseries IX.2: Oleg Prokofiev Papers
Series X: Other Collections
Subseries X.1: Georgii Gorchakov Collection
Subseries X.2: Christopher Palmer Collection
Subseries X.3: Lázár Collection
Subseries X:4: Sir Edward Downes Collection
Subseries X.5: Noëlle Mann Collection

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The SPA is closed to research while it is being catalogued (2015-2016). Each Series will be open for research once cataloging is complete and the Finding Aid is made available online.
The Serge Prokofiev Foundation Archive is accessed by arrangement with the Project Archivist for the Prokofiev Archive

acqinfo.head: Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Serge Prokofiev Archive is on deposit with the Rare Book and Manuscript Library by the Serge Prokofiev Foundation.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of specific item; Date (if known); Serge Prokofiev Archive; Box and Folder; Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection is being processed by Natalia Ermolaev, Velia Ivanova, Michael Ossorgin, and Jennifer Goslee, with assistance from Rita McAllister, 2015-2016.
Finding aid written by Natalia Ermolaev, 2015

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Copyright remains with the creator and his/her heirs. The responsibility to secure copyright permission rests with the patron.

scopecontent.p: This series contains complete works, drafts, sketches, and notes for Prokofiev's musical works: 58 original manuscripts, 153 photocopies, 105 microfilm, and 57 digital items. The material is dated as early as 1899 and as late as 1953, with some items containing annotations added after Prokofiev's death.
The music manuscripts have been thoroughly cataloged to provide information about format, genre, material features, and provenance. Terms include:
Document type: divides manuscripts based on whether they consist of notated music or text.
Format: describes the technology used to produce each item as well as its stage of publication (i.e manuscript, typescript, publication).

Genre: categorizes the musical works themselves (i.e opera, ballet, motion picture music, incidental music, orchestral music, songs with orchestra, symphony, choruses with orchestra, band music, chamber music, instrumental music, songs, piano music).

Content type: if notated music, describes the way the work is scored: full score, short score, short score with instrumental annotations, piano score, piano score with instrumental annotations, arrangement, original workings, vocal score. If text, divides items into categories: libretto, screenplay, concert program, catalog, notes.
Part: describes the completeness of each item (i.e. complete, part, fragment, unknown, various).
Version: describes the stage of creative production shown in each manuscript (i.e. sketch, final, draft).

58 original items: complete works, drafts, sketches, and notes, dated from 1910 to 1934, many of which are written or annotated in Prokofiev's own hand. Highlights include: the sketches, full score, and symphonic suite of The Prodigal Son, sketches and full score of Sur le Borysthène, the full score of Four Portraits(symphonic suite from The Gambler), the original workings, orchestral sketches and full score of Egyptian Nights, the draft full score of Symphony No. 3 with references to The Fiery Angel, the original workings for the Symphonic Song, sketches and drafts of Piano Concerto No. 4 and No. 5, and scores for the piano pieces Choses en soi, Two Sonatinas Op. 54, and Thoughts (or Pensées) Op. 62.
The archive also contains three sketchbooks of musical ideas kept by Prokofiev during the years 1919, 1929 and 1931, and four untitled folders of loose sketches and notes.

note.p: Title as transcribed: Осеннее: Симфонический ескизъ/ Esquisse automnale

Notes: 1914 clean score in black ink with revisions from 1934 in pencil. The French title also appears in pencil, while the Russian title is in ink. End dated February, 15 1934, Paris. The verso of the cover page contains a very short piano sketch of an unidentified passage.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Content type: Full score; Piano score
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil; red crayon

Notes: The first three folia are an full score draft of an inserted scene for end of Act I (around rehearsal No. 102). The remainder is a working out of a piano score of that same scene. Includes a sheet cut off to 12.5 cm x 35 cm size, on which the range of all the vocal parts is written out in what looks like Mikhail Astrov's hand. The front page is marked as "added scene, Act I" ("Вставная сцена, I акт")
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Title as transcribed: Le Joueur; Игрокъ, Der Spieler
Content type: Vocal score with instrumental annotations
Language of text: Russian; French; German
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil. red crayon; blue crayon; purple crayon

Notes: Second version of opera. Final version for engraving. Stamped 'Gravé' in red. Pagination marked in pencil. German text written above the staff in blue ink. French and Russian below in black. Possible cuts to the opera indicated. Act 2 end dated December 12, 1927. Whole work end dated March 6, 1928, Paris A few of the folia contain one-word Russian annotations in a very rough, almost childlike hand that does not look like Prokofiev's. A few of the folia contain paste-overs and corrections. In one instance, there is an added page to be inserted at an earlier spot. In a few of the margins, as well as on the verso of folio 15, the composer has worked out endings of scenes in pencil.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France

did.unittitle: Sonata for Piano No. 4, [1917 (1908) (annotations are most likely from 1934)],

note.p: Title as transcribed: Четвертая соната (Из старых тетрадей)/Quatrième sonate (D'après des vieux cahiers)

Notes: Piano score marked up in composer's hand for orchestration of second movement. A number of rewritten portions are present in the margins. Printed score published by Section musicale des editions d'état (Государственное Издательство Музикалний Сектор) in 1926.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France

did.unittitle: Andante from Sonata for Piano No.4 [for orchestra], 1934,

note.p: Title as transcribed: Оркестровка Andante, Op. 29
Notes: Orchestration of the second movement of the fourth piano sonata. End dated February 8, 1934 Paris.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: pencil; red crayon; blue crayon; blue pen

Notes: Printed score and appended corrections. Score published in 1922 by the State Publishing House in Moscow (Государственное Музыкальное Издательство). Subsequently marked up with corrections and revisions in Prokofiev's hand. Each page of the printed score is stamped "Societé des auteurs, May 16, 1924." There are a number of dates on the score: The original date of composition printed inside is 1917, the cover notes date of publication as 1922, and the title page has the date 1918 printed. In the margin of the title page two more dates are written: сочинил (composed): 1917 and пересмотренный (revised) 1933. A marking in blue crayon on the first page reads "36 parts. Conseil du 30 avril 1924." The title page bears the original subtitle "Кантата" [Cantata], which has been crossed out and corrected to Заклинанiе [Incantation]. Under the printed Russian text the French translation by Louis Laloy is written out. The last seven leaves contain autograph revisions and corrections.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: black ink; blue crayon; green crayon
Notes: Fair draft with very minor corrections - mostly changes to rehearsal numbers. End dated January 13, 1918, Kislovodsk.
Previous holding library: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London
Title as transcribed: Увертюра на еврейские темы/Ouverture in Yiddish Themes/ Ouverture sur Thèmes Juifs

Notes: Printed score for the sextet version with Prokofiev's annotations for orchestration as well as some additional parts written out in pencil in the margins. End dated May 31, 1934, Bugrah. Published by Breitkopf & Hartel, Leipzig in 1922 under plate number A. 10309. G.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Title as transcribed: Der Feurige Engel
Annotations: black ink; pencil; red crayon
Notes: Eight sheets of sketches, followed by a (German) vocal score of the entire opera with annotations and corrections.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: black ink; pencil; red crayon; purple crayon

Notes: Includes all numbers except for the prelude and the finale, although the numeration is slightly different, because this score includes one number (7) unused in the final version. The last folio contains a sketch of the beginning of Symphony No. 2.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Content type: Piano score with instrumental annotations
Annotations: black ink; blue ink; pencil;

Notes: First leaf contains a sketch of the beginning and end of the first movement (Moderato). The back of the next folio contains a partial transposition one tone down of a portion of the movement. The opening theme of the second movement (Nocturne - Larghetto) is sketched several times. Parts of the third movement (Dance - Allegro energico) are sketched in pencil. End dated August 4, 1925. When CU recieved this collection, the last pages of Matelote movement of Trapèze (marked "Divertimento, 1st version") were included here. They are now in SPA 049, BN#23494.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil; red crayon

Notes: Composite score with reference to the parts of the score of the Fiery Angel that have been used to make up the symphony. The score contains many insertions and rearrangements, but few corrections when it comes to notes and rhythms. Movements end dated as follows: - I: September 6, 1928 - II: September 18, 1928 - III: November 3, 1928 - IV: September 25, Vétraz The last two folia contain insertions to earlier parts of the score.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Notes: Sketches. First four folios are sketches of the first piece, the rest is for the second one. Part of second leaf cut off.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Title as transcribed: Притча о блудном сыне
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil; blue crayon; red crayon
Notes: Late draft with a few insertions to different parts of the score and some corrections to musical material. Front page dated December 7, 1928. Fourth number end dated March 14, 1929.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil; red crayon
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Title as transcribed: Сюита из Блудный Сына
Content type: Full score; Short score

Notes: Composite sketch with references to original ballet score. Additions include sparing notation in connecting parts and very few inclusions of new instruments and melodies. Full ending of the fifth movement written out. Front page dated August 15, 1930. Fifth movement end dated October 21, 1930, Paris.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Content type: Full score; Piano score; Corrections
Annotations: black ink; blue ink; pencil; red crayon

Notes: Corrections to the score (particularly to the end of the symphony). This pertains to the 1929 version (op. 47), not the revised 1947 (op. 112) version. Corrections done in two parts. The first half is a piano reduction in black ink with corrections to the coda. The rest is a full score correction to a few different parts in blue ink.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France

did.unittitle: Four Portraits and 'Dénouement' from The Gambler, 1931 (1916),

note.p: Title as transcribed: Сюiта iз iгрока
Notes: Draft dating from 1931 with references to 1928 opera score. Numerous notes and corrections in composer's hand. Fourth movement end dated December 27, 1931.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France

did.unittitle: Four Portraits and 'Dénouement' from The Gambler, [1931],

note.p: Notes: Corrections in full score to portions of the end of the fourth movement - "Polina" with references to rehearsal numbers from the earlier version of the score.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France

did.unittitle: String Quartet No. 1; Sur le Borysthène, 1930,

note.p: Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil

Notes: Movements end dates and running times as follows: - I: July 16, 1930 (5.5 mins) - II: July 21, 1930; Paris (4.5 mins) - III: July 15, 1930 (7 mins) Some parts (beginnings, ends, pivotal points) drafted clearly. The rest is sketched roughly. The last four leaves contain sketches and a working out of a few bars of the full version. Folios 8v and 9r contain a clean sketch for Sur le Borysthène (Number 11 - Act 2, scene 2 Mime scene)
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Title as transcribed: Un Dimanche Soir (crossed out); На Днепре
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; red crayon; pencil

Notes: On the first page, the working title "Un Dimanche soir" has been crossed out and the title На Днепре [Na Dnepre] has been written out in the composer's hand. A few of the movements are not in the same order as in final score. What is marked as movement 2 here is movement 4 in the final version; movements 5 and 6 are switched in the final version. Movements end dated as follows: - II: October 23, 1930 - IV: October 27, 1930 - V: November 6, 1930 - X (final): February 12, 1931; Paris
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Title as transcribed: Un Dimanche Soir (crossed out); Au (crossed out and corrected to Sur) le Borysthène; На Днепре

Notes: Piano reduction of the ballet score. Appears to be the final version before engraving for the rehearsal score, to be published under plate number R.M.V 520 (Pages are marked up in pencil for engraving, although there is no red stamp indicating that this was indeed engraved). Movements do not appear in the same order as in the final version. Pencil markings indicate the new order of movements. Front page dated 1930. End dated February 12, 1931; Paris. On the first page, the working title "Un Dimanche soir" has been crossed out. Then the title "Au Borysthène" has been written in blue ink. Finally the word "Au" has been crossed out in pencil and corrected to "Sur le."
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: blue ink; pencil; red crayon

Notes: Piano draft with some corrections and notes for orchestration. Drafts of most of the movements. Movements are in a slightly different order than final version. At the end of the first scene a note indicates a running time of 16 to 16.5 mins. A note at the end, states the ballet is 1h 15mins long.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: black ink; blue ink; pencil

Notes: Final version for engraving. Prepared for publication under plate numbers R.M.V. 529 - R.M.V. 534. Pagination and line splits (as well as a few very minor annotations) marked in pencil. Originally the titles were marked with numbers, but subsequently the movement numbers have been crossed out. A note in pencil in upper left margin on first page reads "Gravez en format ordinaire. Pagination separée" [Engrave in ordinary format. Separate pagination] and a few of the movements have notes that ask for space to be left for title and dedication. Two of the movements have dedications: The Scherzino to Nicolas Orloff and the Scherzo to Vladimir Horowitz. Folio 14r contains a sketch for another piece. Dates indicated are: I. 1931 (1928) II. [Date erased] III. [No date] IV. 1920 (1931) V. 1930 (1931) VI. 1909(1931)
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Notes: Arrangement of part of the ballet The Prodigal Son (op. 46). Draft in black ink with many annotations and corrections in pencil.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Notes: Arrangement of part of the ballet The Prodigal Son (op. 46). Sketches of various transitional parts with references to rehearsal numbers from the ballet.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Notes: Arrangement of part of Five Songs, op. 35. Sketch of first 21 bars.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Title as transcribed: 4и концерт (для лѣв рукi)
Annotations: blue ink; red crayon; pencil

Notes: Orchestral parts only. No piano part. First page dated 1931. Third movement end dated September 8, 1931; Ciboure. Final movement end dated September 11, 1931; Ciboure. Over certain bars, there are page numbers (perhaps those of the piano draft?) marked in red crayon and in pencil.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: black ink; blue ink; pencil

Notes: Original workings, 1-4 staves. For left hand. Main themes sketched in ink with the rest filled out in pencil. Multiple corrections; hand of Prokofiev and possibly M. Astrov. Third movement end dated August 19, 1931 St Jean de Luz. Fourth movement end dated July 7, 1931, Paris. Near the end, a note states that the piece was finally completed on August 23, 1931 in St. Jean de Luz. The last few folia contain corrections to earlier parts of the piece.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Title as transcribed: Première Sonatine en mi-mineur
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil
Notes: Final version for engraving. Stamped 'Gravé' in red. Pagination marked in pencil. Includes metronome markings. Prepared for publication under plate number R.M.V. 541.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Title as transcribed: Deuxieme Sonatine en Sol-majeur
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil
Notes: Final version for engraving. Stamped 'Gravé' in red. Pagination marked in pencil. Includes metronome markings. Prepared for publication under plate number R.M.V. 542.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil; red crayon

Notes: Rough draft of first movement with corrections; Sketch of fragment of second movement; Three versions of third movement with the last being close to the published version, but with some different transitions between themes. The final leaf is a draft of a very slightly different ending to the piece. Midway through the third movement, the manuscript is dated November 21, 1931.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil
Notes: Complete draft of first and second movements with alterations in transitions. Corrections to third movement show several different beginnings. Ending of third movement missing.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Title as transcribed: Музик для ф. п. с оркестрим/Musique pr piano et orchestre
Notes: Orchestral parts only. No piano part. First page dated March 31, 1932. Movements end dated as follows: - I: June 6, 1932 - II: June 8, 1932 - IV: June 13, 1932 - V: June 24 1932; Paris
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil; red crayon; blue crayon; green crayon
Notes: Contains sketches of all movements, although the one for the third movement is very brief.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Title as transcribed: Соната для двух скрипок/ Sonata pour deux violons
Annotations: black ink; red ink; pencil;

Notes: Although the score is not stamped "Gravé," this appears to be a final version for engraving. Front page bears the address "5, rue Valentin Haüy, Paris XV, France." Score includes markings for bowing and fingering, as well as some changes to tempo and dynamic markings, annotations and very sparing changes to musical material.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Title as transcribed: Соната для двух скрипок
Notes: Full draft. Parts of certain movements sketched on folia between others.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Content type: Piano score with instrumental annotations
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil; green crayon
Notes: Piano sketch in black ink with notes in pencil for orchestration. The last folio contains a sketch, which is identified as an insertion, but does not seem to be from the piece.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil
Notes: Contains a few minor notes about orchestration. Missing a few bars near the end of the piece.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Notes: Rough sketches of part of the second movement.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France

did.unittitle: Three Pieces, for piano (No. 3: Sonatine pastorale), 1934,

note.p: Title as transcribed: Sonatine pastorale (N3, C dur)
Notes: Clean draft in black ink with sparing corrections added in pencil. The end of the score indicates that the piece is 4 minutes long.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France

did.unittitle: Three Pieces, for Piano (no. 3 Sonatine Pastorale), [1933-1934],

note.p: Notes: Most of the piece written out in draft form. Then the rest is in fragments that connect to each other with sequential letters. The last page contains a sketch for another piece.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Title as transcribed: Египетские Ночи: Симфоническая Сюита

Notes: Clean, composite score with references to incidental music. Alterations to parts and to transitional sections written out. End dated September 14, 1934. Movements 2 and 3 switched as are 6 and 7. The verso of folio 4 has notes on instrumentation and transpositions.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil

Notes: Prepared for publication under plate numbers R.M.V 608 and R.M.V. 609. Stamped "Gravé" in red. Pagination marked in pencil. Front page has an annotation reading "Prière de graver en notre format ordinaire. Faire suivre la pagination, mais commencer chaque morceau en haut de la page."
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France

did.unittitle: Arrangement of Twelve Russian Folk Songs (No. 4: White Snow), [1944],

note.p: Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil

Notes: Clean score with very few corrections in pencil. On the first page there is a marking saying that the song should be transposed half a tone up (to D major). This is not true of the final, published version, which is in B major. Folder says 5, but this is 4
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil;
Notes: Drafts of all numbers except 2-5, 7, 10-14, 22, 23, 34, and 35.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Notes: Includes sketches for numbers 2, 10, 16, 18, 19, 24, 26, 27, 29, 35, 44. Contains some instrumental annotations.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Title as transcribed: Египитские Ночи (музыка для камерного театра)
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil; red crayon; blue crayon;

Notes: Full copyist version of incidental music with autograph annotations and corrections. Most corrections are about dynamic and tempo markings as well as reorchestration, but certain bars are crossed off and corrected. Full corrected versions of numbers 2 and 28 are appended at the end. First page is marked (but then crossed out) "А. Я. Таирову, камерный театр, Тверской бульвар, Москва" [A. Y. Tairov, Chamber theater, Tverskoy boulevard, Moscow]
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France

Notes: After a title page, the first seven pages contain revisions and corrections to a score (also present in the copy) published in 1922 by the State Publishing House in Moscow (Государственное Музыкальное Издательство). The printed score is also marked up with corrections and revisions in Prokofiev's hand. Each page is stamped "Societé des auteurs, May 16, 1924." There are a number of dates on the score: The original date of composition printed inside is 1917, the cover notes date of publication as 1922, and the title page has the date 1918 printed. In the margin of the title page two more dates are written: сочинил (composed): 1917 and пересмотренный (revised) 1933. A marking in blue crayon on the first page reads "36 parts. Conseil du 30 avril 1924." The title page bears the original subtitle "Кантата" [Cantata], which has been crossed out and corrected to Заклинанiе [Incantation]. Under the printed Russian text the French translation by Louis Laloy is written out. Pages 21 and 26 of the original present in duplicate.
Previous holding library: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

Notes: Second version of opera. Final version for engraving. Stamped 'Gravé' in red. Pagination marked in pencil. German text written above the staff in blue ink. French and Russian below in black. Possible cuts to the opera indicated. Act 2 end dated December 12, 1927. Whole work end dated March 6, 1928, Paris A few of the folia contain one-word Russian annotations in a very rough, almost childlike hand that does not look like Prokofiev's. A few of the folia contain paste-overs and corrections. In one instance, there is an added page to be inserted at an earlier spot. In a few of the margins, as well as on the verso of folio 15, the composer has worked out endings of scenes in pencil.

Title as transcribed: Соната для виолончели соло

Notes: Work completed by Vladimir Blok, based on Prokofiev's sketches. Includes a preface by Blok explaining the reconstructive process. The parts by Prokofiev are the exposition and the beginning of the development. Blok has continued the development, appended a literal reprise of the first part of the exposition, connected it with a surviving sketch of the recapitulation and then recapitulated the remaining themes of the exposition. Prokofiev's tempo and dynamic markings are indicated with asterisks. Published in Moscow in 1973. Fingerings and bowings in this edition by N. (probably Natalia) Gutman. Wrong opus number printed on the title page, and then corrected in pencil (on the copy) to 134. The title page contains the following hand-written inscription in Russian dated August 21, 1973 from Blok to one Lola Feigin: "Дорогому Лёля Фейгину от одного из многих отнюдь не-Прокофьевых с сердечнни приветем."
Previous holding library: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

did.unittitle: Notes for concert programmes for performances, 1938,

note.p: Notes: Contains Prokofiev's notes for three different concerts: - Baku, November 19,1938. Azerbaijan State Philharmonic, conducted by Leo Ginzburg. The program is said to feature Prokofiev's Romeo and Juliet, Suite No.1 - Moscow, November 26, 1938. USSR State Orchestra conducted by Alexander Melik-Pashayev. The program is said to feature Prokofiev's Cello Concerto, as well as works by Jurowski and Shaporin - Kiev, November 27, 1938. The program is said to feature Prokofiev's Second Violin Concerto in a performance by the violinist B. Fischmann. Part of RGALI item 1929-1-312.

Title as transcribed: Соната для виолончели соло

Notes: Work completed by Vladimir Blok, based on Prokofiev's sketches. Includes a preface by Blok explaining the reconstructive process. The parts by Prokofiev are the exposition and the beginning of the development. Blok has continued the development, appended a literal reprise of the first part of the exposition, connected it with a surviving sketch of the recapitulation and then recapitulated the remaining themes of the exposition. Prokofiev's tempo and dynamic markings are indicated with asterisks. Published in Moscow in 1973. Fingerings and bowings in this edition by N. (probably Natalia) Gutman. Wrong opus number printed on the title page, and then corrected in pencil (on the copy) to 134. The title page contains the following hand-written inscription in Russian dated August 21, 1973 from Blok to one Lola Feigin: "Дорогому Лёля Фейгину от одного из многих отнюдь не-Прокофьевых с сердечнни приветем."
Previous holding library: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

Notes: After a title page, the first seven pages contain autograph revisions and corrections to a score (also present in the copy) published in 1922 by the State Publishing House in Moscow (Государственное Музыкальное Издательство). The printed score is also marked up with corrections and revisions in Prokofiev's hand. Each page is stamped "Societé des auteurs, May 16, 1924." There are a number of dates on the score: The original date of composition printed inside is 1917, the cover notes date of publication as 1922, and the title page has the date 1918 printed. In the margin of the title page two more dates are written: сочинил (composed): 1917 and пересмотренный (revised) 1933. A marking in blue crayon on the first page reads "36 parts. Conseil du 30 avril 1924." The title page bears the original subtitle "Кантата" [Cantata], which has been crossed out and corrected to Заклинанiе [Incantation]. Under the printed Russian text the French transaltion by Louis Laloy is written out. Rendered in different order than the original. Corrections rendered out of order.

scopecontent.p: These papers mainly comprising private and business correspondence relating to the performance and publication of Prokofiev's compositions. Much of the collection consists of personal correspondence concerning his working relationship with other artists including conductors Albert Coates, Sir Henry Wood, Sergei Koussevitsky, Hermann Scherchen, and Ernest Ansermet; soloists Joseph Szigeti, Pablo Casals, Robert Soëtans and Fyodor Shalyapin; composers Igor Stravinsky, Nikolai Miaskovsky, and practically all French composers of the 1920s and 30s; theatre directors Vsevolod Meyerhold and Alexander Tairov; the Director of the Ballets Russes, Serge Diaghilev; poets and writers such as Konstantin Balmont and Vladimir Maiakovsky; and chess grandmaster José Capablanca. The papers also include financial material such as bills and accounts, legal papers and correspondence concerning concerts in the USA, France, Italy, Spain, England, the Soviet Union and Germany; and the publication and copyright of Prokofiev's work. Individuals and companies with which Prokofiev dealt in these matters included musical societies such as the Aeolian Company in the USA, Concerts Populaires de Bruxelles, and Concerts Pasdeloup in Paris; music publishers such as Breitkopf and Härtel in Leipzig, Russicher Musikverlag in Berlin and Edition Russe de Musique in Paris; and Soviet music publishing and arts authorities including the State Publishing House, the Moscow and Leningrad conservatories, and the Direction of State Theatres. There is also correspondence regarding the composition of ballets and operas, notably The Love for Three Oranges, Chout, the Fiery Angel and Le Pas d'Acier. The remainder of the collection consists of diaries, personal notes and press cuttings relating to Prokofiev's work.
Currently, the letters are organized by year and month only. In the future, we will provide detailed information, such as sender, recipient, letter type, etc.

Notes: Front page inscribed "Propriété de Serge Prokofiev" in black marker. The first page contains a pasted on sheet with a typed German translation of this page. Inside, the German translation is written in purple pen in a hand that does not appear to be the composer's. According to an added loose note inside, the German translation may have been made for a performance on October 9, 1926 in Berlin. This score also contains a number of pencil correction to the music and text.
